hints.content: Start by understanding the constraints of the problem. You can only work for a maximum of `sessionTime` hours in one work session, and you must complete any task you start in that session.
Consider the nature of the tasks. Since the maximum task time is guaranteed to be less than or equal to `sessionTime`, you can always fit at least one task into a session.
Think about how you might approach the problem using recursion or backtracking. You could explore different combinations of tasks to see how they fit into the available work sessions.
To optimize your solution, consider using a bitmask to represent the tasks that have been completed. This can help you track which tasks are still available to be scheduled.
When implementing your recursive solution, think about how you can minimize the number of work sessions. You could try to fill each session as much as possible before moving on to the next one.
Consider edge cases, such as when there is only one task or when all tasks are the same. How would your approach change in these scenarios?
As you develop your solution, keep track of the current session time used and the remaining tasks. This will help you decide when to start a new session.
You might want to sort the tasks in descending order before starting the sessions. This can help you fill the sessions more efficiently by tackling larger tasks first.
As you implement the backtracking, ensure that you are correctly counting the number of sessions used. You could maintain a counter that increments each time you start a new session.
Finally, think about how to handle the base case of your recursion. When all tasks have been completed, you should return the total number of sessions used.

questionNotes: Constraints: n == tasks.length, 1 <= n <= 14, 1 <= tasks[i] <= 10, max(tasks[i]) <= sessionTime <= 15.
You can complete tasks in any order.
If you start a task in a work session, you must complete it in that session.
